<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 324, 292]]<|/det|>
## FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9231/22  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 368, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Further Pure Mathematics 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2021

2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 280, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 564, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 364, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 605]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 858, 636]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 665, 220, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 729, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 82, 688, 375]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 392, 920, 440]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve with equation \(y = x^{3}\) for \(0 \leqslant x \leqslant 1\), together with a set of \(n\) rectangles of width \(\frac{1}{n}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 444, 144, 464]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 437, 845, 472]]<|/det|>
By considering the sum of the areas of these rectangles, show that \(\int_{0}^{1} x^{3} \mathrm{~d} x < U_{n}\), where

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 481, 559, 516]]<|/det|>
\[U_{n} = \left(\frac{n + 1}{2n}\right)^{2}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 492, 920, 511]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 81, 146, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 737, 102]]<|/det|>
Use a similar method to find, in terms of \(n\), a lower bound \(L_{n}\) for \(\int_{0}^{1} x^{3} \mathrm{~d} x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 79, 920, 100]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 549, 181, 567]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 72, 737, 102]]<|/det|>
Use a similar method to find, in terms of \(n\), a lower bound \(L_{n}\) for \(\int_{0}^{1} x^{3} \mathrm{~d} x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 75, 920, 100]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 549, 556, 570]]<|/det|>
Find the least value of \(n\) such that \(U_{n} - L_{n} < 10^{-3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 545, 920, 564]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 465, 89]]<|/det|>
Find the solution of the differential equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 95, 603, 127]]<|/det|>
\[\sin \theta \frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}\theta} +y = \tan \frac{1}{2}\theta ,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 131, 821, 152]]<|/det|>
where \(0 < \theta < \pi\), given that \(y = 1\) when \(\theta = \frac{1}{2}\pi\). Give your answer in the form \(y = \mathrm{f}(\theta)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 153, 653, 180]]<|/det|>
[You may use without proof the result that \(\int \cos \theta \mathrm{d}\theta = \ln \tan \frac{1}{2}\theta .\) ]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 191, 917, 210]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 96, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 144, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 601, 94]]<|/det|>
State the sum of the series \(z + z^{2} + z^{3} + \ldots +z^{n}\), for \(z \neq 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 75, 918, 94]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 198, 144, 217]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 198, 823, 217]]<|/det|>
Given that \(z\) is an \(n\)th root of unity and \(z \neq 1\), deduce that \(1 + z + z^{2} + \ldots + z^{n - 1} = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 199, 918, 217]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 384, 141, 403]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 384, 767, 403]]<|/det|>
Given instead that \(z = \frac{1}{3} (\cos \theta + \mathrm{i} \sin \theta)\), use de Moivre's theorem to show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 419, 621, 463]]<|/det|>
\[\sum_{m = 1}^{\infty}3^{-m}\cos m\theta = \frac{3\cos\theta - 1}{10 - 6\cos\theta}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 431, 920, 450]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 316, 89]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{A}\) is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 94, 578, 153]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 5 & -\frac{22}{3} & 8 \\ 0 & -6 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 180, 146, 199]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 178, 660, 199]]<|/det|>
Find a matrix \(\mathbf{P}\) and a diagonal matrix \(\mathbf{D}\) such that \(\mathbf{A}^2 = \mathbf{P}\mathbf{D}\mathbf{P}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 180, 920, 199]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 416, 89]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has parametric equations

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 100, 702, 123]]<|/det|>
\[x = 2\cosh t,\;y = \frac{3}{2} t - \frac{1}{4}\sinh 2t,\;\mathrm{for}\;0\leqslant t\leqslant 1.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 144, 144, 165]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 144, 468, 170]]<|/det|>
Find \(\frac{\mathrm{d}x}{\mathrm{d}t}\) and show that \(\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}t} = 1 - \sinh^2 t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 147, 920, 166]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 368, 920, 388]]<|/det|>
The area of the surface generated when \(C\) is rotated through \(2\pi\) radians about the \(x\)-axis is denoted by \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 395, 144, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 395, 180, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 393, 584, 420]]<|/det|>
Show that \(A = \pi \int_{0}^{1} \left(\frac{3}{2} t - \frac{1}{4} \sinh 2t\right) (1 + \cosh 2t) \mathrm{d}t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 396, 920, 415]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 425, 917, 445]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 73, 181, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 556, 91]]<|/det|>
Hence find \(A\) in terms of \(\pi\), \(\sinh 2\) and \(\cosh 2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 91]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 73, 567, 90]]<|/det|>
# Additional Page  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
If you use the following lined page to complete the answer(s) to any question(s), the question number(s) must be clearly shown.
